III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
One out of two personnel records hired under one year contained central registry
clearances completed more than 30 days prior to the start of employment. The staff
person was hired on 01/10/2022, whereas the central registry was completed on
11/16/2021.
R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of
the following information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and the new
location of the child.
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of the services
provided while in residence, including medical and dental
services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that remain to be
met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan recommendations,
including medical and dental follow up that is needed, have
been reviewed with the resident and with the parent and with
the responsible case manager.
(f) The name and official title of the person to whom the
resident was discharged.
4

One out of eight discharged case records reviewed did not contain a discharge
summary.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the
following:
The facility is not contracted with the DHHS and not subject to ISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract/Policy violation.
Please note that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that
may not be included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional
DHHS Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
The facility is not contracted with the DHHS and not subject to DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's case record:
(c) A brief description of the resident's preparation for placement
and general physical and emotional state at the time of
admission.
The facility’s Face Sheet completed at time of intake does not address the
requirements of this subrule. Requirements of this subrule are contained in the
Management Plan, which is completed the following day by the case manager. This
subrule needs to be completed at time of admission.
R 400.4146 Immunizations.
(1) A resident shall have current immunizations as required by
the department of community health.
5

Youths printed Michigan Care Improvement Registry’s (MCIR) did not contain a
facility staff signature or date. It is recommended the facility document the review of
the MCIR and steps for follow-up if necessary.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were two substantiated incident of substantiated child abuse during this
licensing period.
SIR#2021C0219030 initiated on 02/25/2021 cited the facility for one staff inflicting
corporal punishment when staff placed his forearm to a youth’s neck during restraint.
The corrective action plan resulted in the termination of the involved staff, annual
updated training of all staff in crisis prevention intervention (CPI) refresher training,
staff signing acknowledgment and understanding of facility policies and procedures,
and ongoing review of related policies during weekly team meetings as necessary.
SIR#2022C0217013 initiated on 11/16/2021 cited the facility for one staff inflicting
corporal punishment when staff punched a youth two times after staff was swung at
and spit on by the youth. The facility was also cited for restraint technique for another
staff involved in the same incident. The corrective action plan resulted in the
termination of the initial involved staff, the other staff person meeting with
administration to review proper CPI techniques, and annual updated training of all
staff in CPI. The facility indicates the prior corrective action plan as not being
effective due to the pandemic forcing the facility to modify its refresher training on
crisis prevention and intervention modules.
6

The Interim Inspection Report 04/06/2021 resulted in a corrective action plan for
late/deficient central registry checks, no verification of immunizations, photo at time of
intake, late preliminary service plan, and service plan periods being reported on. The
corrective action plan appears to have been successful as no specific repeat citations
are currently noted.
SIR#2021C0106029 initiated on 06/16/2021 cited the facility for restraint procedures
when staff pushed a youth. The corrective action plan included a refresher training in
crisis prevention intervention and a three-month work plan to meet monthly and
review practices with supervisor.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
